226507: Orzhova.author: uoldgoat
226507: Orzhova.text_parsed:
Design = Good
Flavor = Good
Design + Flavor = BAD

Why do I think that? If I were making an Orzhov-themed Planechase deck (and planar deck), I would focus on creatures with the "Haunt" Orzhov mechanic (see Blind Hunter), and the very first plane I would want to put in would naturally be Orzhova. Bad call. Whenever a Haunt creature dies, it's exiled, so once somebody planeswalks away, a good number of your dead creatures won't see the light of day, whereas all of your opponents' that you didn't exile with the Chaos roll (or other graveyard control) come back to haunt you!

You'd have to have a very nice graveyard (2-3 Angel of Despairs and then some) to make it worth your while AND you have to hope your opponents don't exile it with a good chaos roll. This might be a good one for Joe Boros to add in his deck...

In my opinion the Church of Deals dealt itself aces and eights on this hand. Good thing most of them are already dead...

226512: Akoum.text_parsed: This card has two major downsides.  The first is that giving enchantments flash is frequently of little or no relevance (though when it is relevant it could be big). It would be nice if it were a "may" effect or specified "target creature an opponent controls."

226512: Akoum.text_parsed:
"Edged beauty" defines the volcanic continent of Akoum more than any other concept—the crystalline fields shimmer in every imaginable color beneath the sun, but the deceptively sharp edges of even the most mundane surface stones will slice through leather and flesh if an unwary traveler should slip and fall. The surface can reach incredible temperature extremes, as the omnipresent silicate stone reflects the sun's glaring light and will cook an unprepared traveler during the day just as quickly as that cold stone will freeze one at night.
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/stf/73

226526: Astral Arena.author: Etsap
226526: Astral Arena.text_parsed: I don't like planes with this kind of negative tension on the planar die.  If I'm the guy with the swarm of 1/1 tokens, then I'm the one that most wants to leave, but who least wants to roll chaos.  This means that everyone else may have strong incentive not to roll the planar die because staying keeps them alive, but I may not be able to risk rolling it because a bad roll means I lose.  Thus the entire game comes to a stall.

226527: Edge of Malacol.author: Etsap
226527: Edge of Malacol.text_parsed: This card treads dangerously close to The Eon Fog, but thankfully the Stasis effect is limited to creatures, so players don't have to feel like they are stuck doing nothing. This card definitely slows down a game by encouraging players not to attack or rendering them unable to attack. Ordinarily it will provide incentive to roll the planar die, but can occasionally be a problem since planeswalking away means all of your opponents get to untap first.

226533: Takenuma.author: RJDroid
226533: Takenuma.text_parsed:
Having played around with this, the card advantage you get when playing with ninjas is just obscene.
Attacking with a single Baleful Strix, ninjutsuing in Ninja of the Deep Hours, and drawing two cards is bonkers, even in a group setting. If you have the mana to cast Baleful Strix again, you draw another card, and yet another card when you roll chaos. That's 4 cards there, and your board situation has remained the same or even improved.

That's just with one unblocked creature.

Of course, the opponent gets to draw cards when their creatures die, but the advantage is overwhelmingly in your favor with the ninja deck.

226534: Kharasha Foothills.author: Etsap
226534: Kharasha Foothills.text_parsed: Unfortunately, this won't trigger Grave Titan or anything else that triggers on attacking more than once. The token copies are put onto the battlefield tapped and attacking, which means they exist past the point that attack triggers are checked. (Check the rulings under Kaalia of the Vast for confirmation). Your original titan will trigger, but the copies won't. On the upside, however, your original attacker will have to pay costs to attack (such as on Propaganda or Norn's Annex), but the copies won't, so any player that is hiding behind those cards becomes defenseless with this plane active. This card is lots of fun in multi-player, especially if you have creatures that do interesting things in combat like deathtouch or lifelink, or abilities that trigger on dealing combat damage.
226534: Kharasha Foothills.text_posted: Unfortunately, this won't trigger [autocard]Grave Titan[/autocard] or anything else that triggers on attacking more than once. 226544: Hedron Fields of Agadeem.author: Doom_Lich
226544: Hedron Fields of Agadeem.text_parsed:
@Reck13ssDriver: Once something has been declared attacking it can't be stopped by static effects. Sakashima's student enters the battlefield already attacking, so Hedron Fields has no chance to say "No."

Similarly, with firebreathing you swing with say a 5/5 dragon, and after declaring attackers you pump him to an 8/8. It's already attacking so Hedron fields can't stop it.

Long story short: Hedron Fields only checks if something can attack or block when it's first declared attacking or blocking. (And with ninjutsu it was NEVER declared attacking so ninjutsu'd creatures aren't stopped by this.

226546: Spatial Merging.author: FelixCarter
226546: Spatial Merging.text_parsed:
Looks like Chandra Naalar has a beef to pick with Erindae Firestrider. :P

In all seriousness, this is a very interesting concept (much like a lot of other Planechase-related mechanics and card). Pools of Becoming was a very powerful plane if one managed to land a chaos roll, and this phenomenon somehow gives a sense of a very similar - and less overpowering - effect. However, here are some questions concerning game play that the phenomenon has left undefined. Who chooses which plane effect occurs first at any given time? When you roll Chaos, do both effects actuate? I assume that when you planeswalk away from the two planes, you put them on the bottom of the planar deck in any order? Also noteworthy, this is the only phenomenon that does not say, "Then planeswalk away from this phenomenon." Regardless of the many questions, this is fascinating.

Congratulations on your first Planechase card, Gabor Szikszai! The art is simply wonderful. The multiple colors utilized give a strong sense of contrast, but are not so strong that the image becomes cluttered with neon values. The slow transition from fiery hues to earthly shades is done superbly, and the diagonally-placed blue crevice creates a firm distinction from both sides.

226546: Spatial Merging.author: Etsap
226546: Spatial Merging.text_parsed: For all of those rules questions, the person whose turn it is is the planar controller, and the controller of any triggered abilities that trigger simultaneously decides which order to put them on the stack.  So if you roll chaos, you decide which order to stack the effects.  If both planes have an upkeep trigger, the active player decides which order they go on the stack.  Ditto for if both planes have a "when you planeswalk to" trigger.
226546: Spatial Merging.text_posted: For all of those rules questions, the person whose turn it is is the planar controller, and the controller of any triggered abilities that trigger simultaneously decides which order to put them on the stack. Ditto for if both planes have a "when you planeswalk to" trigger.

226556: Time Distortion.author: Etsap
226556: Time Distortion.text_parsed: This doesn't seem like a good idea. The person who encounters it gets no benefit, but the person before them gets two turns in a row (almost). The person who would have been next has to wait a whole rotation. Most casual players tend to frown on Time Warp effects, as they can get pretty degenerate in a hurry. This is why they printed Stranglehold.

265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.author: Trygon_Predator
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_parsed:
This has got to be the Johnnyest card in this set.Offhand, I can see this minotaur playing nicely with Animar, Soul of Elements. With the right amount of counters on Animar, you can play the minotaur for , cascade, and then bounce for another go. If you've already got Aluren in play, shenanigans will happen.
Good to see Minotaurs getting some love too, and it seems like they could be good contenders for a or tribe (see also Zedruu the Greathearted, Minotaur Illusionist, and Raka Disciple).
Finally, the flavor is excellent too. Looks like the Naya minotaurs have been learning a few tricks from Esper.
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_posted:
This has got to be the Johnnyest card in this set.Offhand, I can see this minotaur playing nicely with [autocard]Animar, Soul of Elements[/autocard]. With the right amount of counters on Animar, you can play the minotaur for [U][R], cascade, and then bounce for another go. If you've already got Aluren in play, shenanigans will happen.
Good to see Minotaurs getting some love too, and it seems like they could be good contenders for a [U][R] or [R][U][W] tribe (see also [autocard]Zedruu the Greathearted[/autocard], [autocard]Minotaur Illusionist[/autocard], and [autocard]Raka Disciple[/autocard]).
Finally, the flavor is excellent too. Looks like the Naya minotaurs have been learning a few tricks from Esper.

265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.author: nirvava
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_parsed:
@Sarroth

Concerning Etherium-Horn Sorcerer and Didgeridoo, I think the errata really screwed up the original intention of the artifact. "...As though it were just summoned" implies that the Minotaur the caster is putting into play should be treated as though it were just cast. Aether Storm should've prevented the Didgeridoo's effect (whether that's how it was judged back then or not). For some odd reason, the errata just totally gutted one half of this card for no reason whatsoever.

That being said, you're right. Whoever's responsible for errata should be a tad more careful.

265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.author: Mode
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_parsed:
At first I thought
"Wait, what? I don't get it. This looks like a junk common you'd not want to play in any kind of format. Being a Minotaur Wizard with etherium horns makes him flavorwise incredibly awesome, but that wouldn't make it a rare card or give it a community rating of roughly 4.0 ... Did i miss something?"
Then i realized: I did.

Cascade.

Well, this makes this guy all of a sudden a whole lot more interesting!

265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.author: Stinga
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_parsed: As I said on Lord of Shatterskull Pass this mino is saved by not being too broken with the Didgeridoo: Using the Didgeridoo does not proc the cascade so you are getting a (damn good) 3/6 for 4 and slight card disadvantage (assuming you only use the didger once, you use two cards to put it out. I hope we see more ways to work around it in the future!

265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.author: YertleTheTurtle
265144: Etherium-Horn Sorcerer.text_parsed:
@nirvava

the "as though it were just summoned" clause on Didgeridoo's printed text refers to the fact that the Minotaur is summoning sick which needed to be clarified when the card was first printed in homelands. This was dropped because this type of interaction has become more common. Didgeridoo never caused the Minotaur to be cast. a fact made clear in the original text by the phrase "put it directly into play" showing the Minotaur it self never goes on the stack.

So the errata text is just a simplification of the original text and in no way "screwed up the original intention of the artifact"

Never judge a card for it's worst instance. If you're going to downvote this card, do it because you legitimately believe it isn't good for your planechase deck. Don't downvote it because you're a "HURR NOT GOOD IN STANDARD DURR."

You're not going to downvote that Cavern of Souls just because you run an instant and sorcery deck, are you?

You're not going to downvote that Strangleroot Geist just because you play red white aggro (as opposed to green aggro), are you?

I'm glad for this card, I love it. Two mana accel is great, extra helping of planechase is even better (especially in planechase) And no, this is not strictly comparable to Command Tower because Fractured Powerstone will still give you mana when you don't play a planechase game, where command tower does not.

Also, AWESOME Thran reference. I'm totally digging this extra flavor from ancient sets.

265151: Fractured Powerstone.author: The_Murderauder
265151: Fractured Powerstone.text_parsed:
Yes, this is good mostly in Planechase. And yes, that is primarily how it should be judged.

But, having only played Planechase maybe twice, ever (and not having had this card in either of those games), I can still safely say that I love this card. I run a Kozilek, Butcher of Truth EDH deck which is probably 60% acceleration, and I play every single 2-drop mana rock that's available to me. The difference between a 2-drop rock and a 3-drop rock is deceptively huge. There are very few options for colorless 2-drop mana rocks, and I was glad to have another.

I may only see it in maybe a quarter of the games I play, but it really counts every time, Planechase or not.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: ClockworkSwordfish
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
When I first saw this, I was surprised double cascade hadn't been done before. It seems like this set is being used to do things like this, i.e. make cards they wish they had made when the mechanic was out (See also Thromok).
As for the card, it is cool. 8 mana in three colours for a 7/5 is bad. But stapled to TWO free spells, it is practically a steal. Add in that you get haste for the 7/5 AND any creatures you may cascade into, and this is a massively swingy creature. Look at it this way, Bloodbraid Elf does less than what half of this does.
As for EDH, yes. It can be built around, but it also fits in VERY nicely with Animar's Elementals. Plus, you cast this creature and then the two you cascade into. So, from just an Animar, you can easily put your entire hand onto the board, cascade at least twice, then attack with all creatures in your hand and the cascaded ones AND beefier Animar. Expect to see this guy.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: StreamHopper
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
I've been deciding whether or not to comment on this for days, but I feel like this just has to be said.

I hate this card.

No, not because I lost to it on several occasions (because I have). The problem I have with this card is that there's hardly ANY coming back from it. It stops games almost immediately after it hits the field. I'm the kind of player who doesn't play magic for "infinite combos", "Huge Creatures", or "Expensive decks that win immediately". I play because the game takes a lot of thought and consideration when choosing who to swing with, and who to leave blocking. Which mana to tap, and which to leave open. When the best time is to drop the card you've been holding since the beginning of the game. I LOVE the thinking aspect in it, and I'm having the MOST fun when there's a war going on.

I have four creatures. My opponent has five. We're playing all our combat tricks here, and soon we'll be top-decking. It comes down to who is smarter about who their attackers and blockers are. How to spot a bluff, and exploit an opening they didn't know they had. It's beautiful, and I love the tactical game that comes down to who trumped who with superior strategy. Now let's introduce this card.

I'm in that moment. I'm starting to win through careful consideration, and meticulous calculation. Thinking several turns ahead as to what I'll have, and what my opponent might have. I've set a plan in motion that I believe is superior to his, and now I'm looking for that combat trick in my deck to help me push through.

Oh wait, he played this thing. And he cascaded into another huge thing, that cascaded into another huge thing. Oh, and they all have haste. Great. So he swings all out, and I HAVE to block just to HOPE to survive. There goes all my planning. Because of one broken as all hell card that stopped the game entirely, and with little to no thought, my opponent has the game in his grasp, and I can't do shit about it. Thanks Wizards. If it was just the creature I had to kill, it might not be so bad. But I have to deal with the entire army it brought with it. Oh, and I have to deal with the new army NOW. No time to think about it, and maybe employ a strategy in my mind. That single card has ruined 4 out of the 10 Planeschase games I've played against that deck so far. I don't think I'll be playing it much anymore.

But no.

5/5

FUN.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: Whales
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
@ Damia

No. Casting Natural Order to cheat out a creature with Cascade, or any other effect that says "When you cast..." (i.e. Artisan of Kozilek) won't trigger that card's ability. A spell is only considered "cast" when you spend it's mana cost to actually cast it from your hand. However, if you use Natural Order to put a creature with an "Enters the battlefield" - effect into play, that ability will trigger.
Hope that helps :)
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_posted:
@ Damia

No. Casting [autocard]Natural Order[/autocard] to cheat out a creature with Cascade, or any other effect that says "When you cast..." (i.e. [autocard]Artisan of Kozilek[/autocard]) won't trigger that card's ability. A spell is only considered "cast" when you spend it's mana cost to actually cast it from your hand. [b]However[/b], if you use Natural Order to put a creature with an "Enters the battlefield" - effect into play, that ability [b]will[/b] trigger.
Hope that helps :)

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: alblast
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
so in edh what are the 2 best creatures to come out of Maelstrom's cascades? I think the best situation is that you cascade into a hamelback goliath and then into a clone copying hamelback goliath.

the first one will come into play as a 6/6. The cloned one will come into play as a 6/6 and the first one will be a 12/12. Then Maelstrom Wanderer will come in and make the first Goliath a 19/19 and the second one a 13/13. Altogether you will have 39 points of power originally from 1 creature. You won't quite be able to one shot someone, but it'll be damned close. So is there anything better?

This guy look like fun. Someday I will make a deck with this guy at the helm.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: JaxsonBateman
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
There's definitely better than the simplicity of three big creatures (especially given that the three of them can be stopped by Hornet Queen's tokens). The two best plays I've had with my Wanderer decks (usually alongside Scroll Rack for maximum benefit):

2. Wanderer into Kiki-Jiki and Eternal Witness, with Time Warp already in the graveyard, and 5 mana left up to recast the Time Warp. People hate infinite turn losses, but it's one of those handy trios in a URG EDH deck where all three cards are good on their own, but together theyr'e a win con.

However, my best one:

1. Third turn Wanderer into Bribery and some other irrelevant spell (Far Wanderings or something). However, my opponent was tapped out, had no blockers, and had a Magister Sphinx in his library. One of the fastest EDH wins I've had the pleasure of piloting.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: Yozuk
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed: As a Primary Blue black player this sort of card shouldn't appeal to me. The Lack of control this creature provide is just unreal. Then combine this with Storm, Buyback, kicker and the chaos just increases. What will happen when this thing hits the field? Will it be met with no resistance because nothing is left after you hit a Devastation Tide and a Destructive force? Or do you hit something with much less impact, like a Crystal Ball and a Birds of Paradise? This sort of unknown possibility in this card terrifies the blue player in me. Me being some one who likes being in control. But the Chaos this card inspires brings out a carnal desire I have. This card will find a place as one of my Commanders.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: eksentrysyti
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
I run Maelstrom in the Animar EDH set up, usually making him a simple RUG to cast. Often I find that having Momir Vig, Simic Visionary is game ending when Maestrom hits the board. Stack the triggers like this: Momir blue, cascade, cascade, momir green. Momir green fetches Avenger of Zendikar. Cascade plays Avenger, triggering another Momir green. Momir green fetches Primeval Titan dropping a couple lands to pump Avenger's plants to 2/3's and triggering another Momir green. Fetch something like Solemn Simulacrum. Momir blue resolves, giving Solemn in hand and by now, he's usually free with Animar's stack of counters. Drop Solemn and make them plants into 3/4's. Drop your land for the turn for 4/5 plants. And then... iono, swing with your mass hasted army? Primeval drops a couple more lands and pumps the plants to 6/7.

I dunno about you, but from just having a momir vig, an animar, and enough mana to cast maestrom, you come out swinging with...
Maelstrom (7/5)
Primeval Titan (6/6 trample)
Avenger of Zendikar (5/5)
5+ Plants (6/7) depending on how many lands you had
Solemn (2/2) why not, he's more useful dead
Not to mention you didn't have to draw Primeval or Avenger either.

And even if you didn't have Momir Vig, the randomness is still exciting.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: uoldgoat
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
Most people seem to have enjoyed this card as soon as it was previewed, but I shouted "NOOO!!! Why couldn't it have costed 1 more mana????"

One of my top 10 favorite multiplayer casual decks to play involves using Grozoth to tutor up 14-20 CMC 9 cards to my hand and then Myojin of Life's Web to put every single one of those into play (I use things like Dream Halls and Keeper of Progenitus to cast it from my hand but Flash or Show and Tell on Grozoth). The big hole in the deck is haste. Sure I could use a Concordant Crossroads, but having a 9 CMC creature that gives all your boys haste is way more elegant and awesome. Plus it ensures at least one big swing before I get Wrathed.

This wouldn't have just benefited this deck though. Just look at all the fun CMC 8 stuff it could have cascaded into:

Akroma, Angel of Wrath (and her red alter ego)
Avacyn, Angel of Hope
Griselbrand
Avatar of Woe (Woah! Haste on her is good)
Bogarden Hellkite
Craterhoof Behemoth
Godsire
Verdant Force
Woodfall Primus

Oh well, better luck next summer! :-/

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: TheWrathofShane
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
What happens when you cascade into something with cascade? I think the new cascade would go on top of his 2nd cascade then after the new one resolves you complete his 2nd cascade. Unless of course the new cascade, cascades into another cascade. Then your opponent is free to flip the table.

@kajisama
No, you have to "cast" something with cascade for the ability to trigger. Flash does not "cast" the card, it just puts it into play. In this same way, cloudshift affects will not work, but unsummon + recasting will.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: ElCarl
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
Recent occurence in an EDH game that demonstrates the chaotic hilarity that cascade produces:

On 5 life, in a pretty bad way generally.
Maelstrom Nexus on the battlefield, cast Maelstrom Wanderer. Triple 8-CMC cascade incoming:
1st cascade: Bituminous Blast, which cascades into Sakashima the Impostor.
2nd cascade: Stormcaller's Boon, cascading into Worldly Tutor.
3rd cascade: Cruel Ultimatum

That would have been awesome, had Wild Ricochet not been played at that point.
Sigh.

265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.author: mdakw576
265154: Maelstrom Wanderer.text_parsed:
very powerful general in EDH. In a properly designed deck, you will usually be happy with whatever you cascade into, be it a 1 mana sol ring or your 6 mana consecrated sphinx. You then get a creature that kills in 3 hits and that's if it's just killing from general damage, since mass haste means you can easily win with just mass creatures. Find ways to willingly sacrifice wanderer or bounce it to your hand (ex; food chain, crystal shard) to get the cascade triggers again, and you will win with sheer card advantage.

It's not a tier 1 general in 1v1 EDH, because the randomness of cascade does affect the consistency of the deck. But it's definitely a deck to be wary of, particularly if you do hit good cascades.

265155: Thromok the Insatiable.author: TreeTrunkMaster
265155: Thromok the Insatiable.text_parsed:
Crazy! I think you could argue that this card would be too powerful if it had trample or shroud/hexproof at this cost.
10 creatures sacked = 100/100!

Another way to think about the calculation if anyone is getting mixed up (or just doesn't like math):
number of creatures sacrificed times that same number
So, 8 creatures sacked: 8 X 8 = 64
Also known as squaring the number if you're familiar with that. So take the number of creatures sacrificed and square that number.

265155: Thromok the Insatiable.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
265155: Thromok the Insatiable.text_parsed:
*nitpick*
This is a geometric worm, not an exponential one! The phrase "exponential" seems to be used by many without understanding what it means.

The Devour X means the hellion's size grows geometrically:
1 --> 1² = 1
2 --> 2² = 4
3 --> 3² = 9
4 --> 4² = 16
5 --> 5² = 25

A true exponential worm would grow as e^x, such as:

1 --> e^1 = 3 (rounded up always)
2 --> e^2 = 8
3 --> e^3 = 21
4 --> e^4 = 55
5 --> e^5 = 149

Also, longs for trampling and hasting...
*/nitpick*

265155: Thromok the Insatiable.author: EtherBunny41
265155: Thromok the Insatiable.text_parsed:
EDH, this as General. Feed the Pack. Let's say you starrt off sacking 5 creatures to make him a 25/25, then break him open at the end of turn for 25 2/2s. Then next turn you pay 7 and sack those 25 for a 625/625. At end of turn, break him again, giving you an army of 625 2/2 wolves. And then on the next turn, if you're feeling particularly dickholish, pay 9 mana for (I shit you not) a 390,625/390,625. And then break him AGAIN if you want to.

Now, this of course implies perfect casting conditions, but seriously, three turns and he's into six digit numbers. One more and he hits the billions. It's kind of ridiculous, but in the most lovely of ways.

265155: Thromok the Insatiable.author: seahen
265155: Thromok the Insatiable.text_parsed:
@EtherBunny41 Even better with Doubling Season or Primal Vigor -- the power and toughness get doubled once when the counters become tokens, and again when the tokens are devoured. So if you start by devouring 5 creatures, you get a 50/50 Thromok, then 100 tokens, then a 20,000/20,000 Thromok, then 40,000 tokens, then a 3,200,000,000/3,200,000,000 Thromok.

The formula for Thromok's power and toughness, if he starts by devouring X creatures and is being summoned for the Nth time, is X^2^N. Each Doubling Season or Primal Vigor multiplies it by 2^(2^N - 1).

Still won't grow as fast as the combos that involve cloning Doubling Season or Primal Vigor, which can give you on the order of 2↑↑N tokens.

265155: Thromok the Insatiable.author: Enelysios
265155: Thromok the Insatiable.text_parsed:
A really neat card, but not very good. The only time I have ever seen it win a game is when used as a psuedo-burn-spell by putting out a pandemonium the turn before. That was cool, but every other time he has been cast by one of my friends, he has been killed. This is one instance where the 'dies to removal' argument is actually valid, because you are giving up a lot of card advantage here for a creature without haste.

This guy is so reliant on board position he becomes almost unplayable. You need to have creatures to sac to him (Absolute minimum 3, hopefully at least 5.) A way to protect him or take advantage of him. (Fires of Yavimaya, Pandemonium, Asceticism) and if you want to attack, a way to grant him trample. (Rancor seems thematic) He is cool, but so risky that even my Timmiest of friends are usually content just to have a 100/100 creature and don't anticipate getting much use. I feel bad every time I vapor snag him.

265156: Baleful Strix.author: Trygon_Predator
265156: Baleful Strix.text_parsed:
I really want to like this card. On one hand, it's a frickin' robot owl of doom that replaces itself and gives you a deathtoucher. On the other hand, it's unabashedly overpowered (in the words of Aaron Forsythe: "it is fun because it is overpowered (too good for Standard)") and would not have been printed outside of a casual supplement like Planechase. And finally, I'm disappointed in the competition this gives to Coiling Oracle. Whatever happened to having the best creatures? Looks like is stealing its thunder now. Everyone's favorite Snake Elf Druid had better get an upgrade in the new Ravnica block.
... sigh. This card is better than it has a right to. And this may or may not be a bad thing.

This creature, Just by itself:

. Has flying, which can be turned into a considerable life loss for your opponent.

. Is a black artifact creature, saving itself from a bunch of removal spells.

How can you not love this little owl?
Rating 5 out of 5 for me!

265156: Baleful Strix.text_parsed:
For anyone to complain how 'blatantly OP this card is' lets look at a few facts about it first.

1) It can only be put into a deck, or a deck. It would defiantly make decks stronger with the card, but it isn't exactly something that would make this blatantly Overpowered. In my opinion, color balance has just as much effect on the 'balance' of a card then core sets or not.

2) Second, drawing a card is nice, as it replaces a card in the hand. But as much as it is drawing a card, that said card could mean that you just have an extra land when you don't need it, or a huge creature that you can't play. Top-decking draw cards with a card like this is a lot harder unless you use production methods, and because it doesn't have flash it also increases your chance of a dead miracle in hand.

3) Flying is decent, and deathtouch is also good, but being that it is only a 1/1 for it would mean that it could kill one thing unless made indestructible.

4) If this WAS printed in a core set, Mirradin would be out of standard, meaning you CAN'T use swords with it.

A very fun card but shouldn't have been printed and it's just a good thing its legal in the formats that have access to much better cards 5/5 for sure

265156: Baleful Strix.author: Ultimario
265156: Baleful Strix.text_parsed: Seems like something out of Urza Block - it perfectly and efficiently fulfills its intended role to a horrifying extent (a 0-for-1 trade when it blocks which scares off multiple giant creatures from all of your opponents, and a cantripping nigh-unblockable (good luck getting an advantage out of blocking this with anything other than a token or first-strike flier) attacker for ninjitsu, that also lets you draw more cards over the course of the game because of ninjitsu's bouncing). Unlike most cards in Urza Block, it's only slightly overpowered/undercosted in a way that's still fun to use rather than comboing out instantly in an unfair way. It really makes you wonder what they would've priced this monster if they had to worry about Standard - 2UB maybe?

265156: Baleful Strix.author: Clicka
265156: Baleful Strix.text_parsed:
Putting it into perspective, here are a couple situations that provide further evidence stating this card is utility all the way.

Best case scenario: If it comes out and instantly gets bolted, you virtually just played a less pressure inducing Hymn to Tourach, specifically in terms of CMC and card advantage- and forced an answer to be discarded.

Worst case scenario: they allow the card to stay, and you have a 1/1 that can block to put you up in card advantage +1, unless they don't attack whatsoever, which in Legacy is possible.

265159: Sakashima's Student.author: MetalViolin
265159: Sakashima's Student.text_parsed:
Oddly enough, I see this card having better use outside of a ninja deck than within one. Many of the ninjas have a fairly low cost ninjutsu ability (aside from the legendary ninjas, but copying them is just pointless), meaning Sakashima's Student is not a cheap replacement for good ninjas for the most part.

Outside of a ninja deck, no one expects it when a Spark Elemental suddenly turns into a ninja that clones your Khalni Hydra. The great thing is that this card is just like Clone in that it can copy hexproof or shroud creatures.

270724: Indrik Umbra.author: Brawler_1337
270724: Indrik Umbra.text_parsed:
I agree with MANABURN. This card does seem to be made for Uril EDH decks given its color identity and cost. I use it in my Uril deck. I don't usually hook it up to Uril, though, since it's more useful for clearing the way for Uril to inflict huge General damage.

My favorite combo with it is to hook it up to Wurmcoil Engine. Ten of my opponent's creatures die, I gain ten life, and Wurmcoil isn't getting touched unless my opponent has 10+ first strike damage on the board. (Even with that, all that does is get rid of Indrik Umbra; there's still a Wurmcoil Engine to deal with after that.) Combine with a trample-giving Aura like Rancor for even more hilarity.

270725: Elderwood Scion.author: sarroth
270725: Elderwood Scion.text_parsed:
@Vedalken_Arbiter @ SocialExperiment: all aura spells target the permanent or player they're enchanting when you cast the enchantment card. See Rule 114.1b It's in their full rules text, which they probably should have kept as reminder text because people forget this a lot. Yes, Oblivion Ring and similar cards (e.g, Journey to Nowhere and Exclusion Ritual) don't target as spells but as permanents, but they're not auras.

This is such a great card. I love enchantment decks. They can be really powerful despite the card disadvantage of auras, and cards like this really help.
270725: Elderwood Scion.text_posted:
@Vedalken_Arbiter @ SocialExperiment: [i]all aura spells target the permanent or player they're enchanting when you cast the enchantment card[/i]. See Rule 114.1b It's in their full rules text, which they probably should have kept as reminder text because people forget this a lot. Yes, [autocard]Oblivion Ring[/autocard] and similar cards (e.g, [autocard]Journey to Nowhere[/autocard] and [autocard]Exclusion Ritual[/autocard]) don't target as spells but as permanents, [i]but they're not auras[/i].

This is such a great card. I love enchantment decks. They can be really powerful despite the card disadvantage of auras, and cards like this really help.

270725: Elderwood Scion.author: SocialExperiment
270725: Elderwood Scion.text_parsed:
@Vedalken_Arbiter
Yes, because Auras that don't target as they cast are the ones like Oblivion Ring, which use triggered abilities (and isn't actually an Aura at all, because Oblivion Ring would self destruct if it was). "Enchant creature/permanent" Auras would get the reduced cost.
270725: Elderwood Scion.text_posted:
@Vedalken_Arbiter
Yes, because Auras that don't target as they cast are the ones like Oblivion Ring, which use triggered abilities (and isn't actually an Aura at all, because Oblivion Ring would self destruct if it was). "Enchant creature/permanent" Auras would get the reduced cost.

270726: Dragonlair Spider.author: DarthParallax
270726: Dragonlair Spider.text_parsed:
Filler card in Commander's Arsenal. I hope it's loved enough by Spider Players.

I think so far it's the only card revealed that's depressingly unexciting for such a highly anticipated product. However, I offer this explanation: The Planechase 2012 and Commander cards have some favoritism to get picked because they've never appeared in Foil before, and also they were designed mostly with this format in mind. I'm sure that Planechase-Commander and Archenemy-Commander get played MUCH more heavily than 60c-PC or 60c-AE.

I'm not yet calling 'it's the Desert of the set' until other people start hating on it- until then, it's 'the Kird Ape of the set'- ie might actually be desired even if it's unvaluable.

270729: Vela the Night-Clad.author: Yozuk
270729: Vela the Night-Clad.text_parsed:
So I'm trying to determine if this is a good card or not. I mean for Commander, not for other formats. So the first ability matches Bellowing Tanglewurm's ability except this gives intimidate to all your creatures regardless of their color. Another card I can compare that ability to is Cover of Darkness. A good, yet narrow card. Personally I would use cover of darkness over her in a ninja deck but that isn't what we are looking at. But the closest enchantment would be Intimidation. Now I know intimidate is often considered better then fear. But I would disagree with you. Sure, Moonlace makes your creature with intimidate unblockable by everything except for artifacts, but are you really going to use a slot in your deck for that card? I didn't think so. Plus for each color your creature is it becomes more and more likely that they are going to be blocked.
So I ask again. Is Giving all your creatures intimidate worth a mythic spot? Not sure. Is it worth a rare slot? I would like to think it is. Eldrazi and artifact creatures seem to be the best cards to benefit from her. As for her last ability. When ever a creature or Vela enters the battlefield each opponent loses one life. Hmm. I tried to find a card that matched that ability but just couldn't. The ability seems more like an annoyance then a threat. But then again thats all you might need. The closest thing I could find to that effect was Vigilante Justice and Psychosis Crawler. Although Justice is damage and targets and crawler is when you draw cards.
But does this maker her mythic worthy? And I think my conclusion is yes. Her intimidate ability wouldn't make her worthy of the title. But the unusual ability to cause life loss to each opponent when she or other creature enter the battlefield under your control with that ability does fill the niche that is sometimes required for mythic status.

Over all, I'm excited for the Ninja deck and can't wait to get my copy.

270729: Vela the Night-Clad.text_parsed:
Vela has some nice artwork, and the leave play ability screams "Break me!" She deters boards wipes, makes combos, and makes your stuff harder to block. She's great in the precon or as a Commander in EDH. Speaking of the precon,I love the synergy that the Ninja deck has.

all the Ninjas have combo potential with her, both in their Ninjutsu abilities and in the intimidate.
However, almost all the other cards combo well with the Ninjas too. Bounce a Baleful Strix and draw another card. Bounce a Augery Owl and Scry 3 again. The unblockables help you hit your Ninjutsus, and the Sai of the Shinobis give your ninjas more umph when they sneak in. All in all a great precon.

Vela has some nice artwork, and the leave play ability screams "Break me!"  She deters boards wipes, makes combos, and makes your stuff harder to block.  She's great in the precon or as a Commander in EDH.  Speaking of the precon,I love the synergy that the Ninja deck has.

all the Ninjas have combo potential with her, both in their Ninjutsu abilities and in the intimidate.
However, almost all the other cards combo well with the Ninjas too.  Bounce a [autocard]Baleful Strix[/autocard] and draw another card.  Bounce a [autocard]Augery Owl[/autocard] and Scry 3 again.  The unblockables help you hit your Ninjutsus, and the [autocard]Sai of the Shinobi[/autocard]s   give your ninjas more umph when they sneak in.  All in all a great precon.

270729: Vela the Night-Clad.author: tankthebest
270729: Vela the Night-Clad.text_parsed:
I really, really wanted to like this card. After all, it's tailor-made for Ninjas, as others have mentioned. But after playing the deck as is, then modified, then modified without Vela, I have to say the third option works best.

What she does is obviously awesome for Ninjas, but she just shows up too late to make a noticeable difference in a game. Typically by the time I got her out my strategy had switched from using ninjutsu on my small unblockable creatures to simply swinging for the win with my finishers (Higure, the Still Wind, Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni, and Silent-Blade Oni) and cards like Distortion Strike and Shadow Rift. In the games that I played, I think the most life she caused my opponent to lose was 4.

Overall I think she would have been much more useful had she been a two- or even three-drop. This is just my experience though, yours may differ.

270733: Shardless Agent.author: Mode
270733: Shardless Agent.text_parsed:
Faerie Impostor has a great synergy with this.
Didn't cascade into the spell you wanted yet?
Bounce your agent and try again, maybe you get your Ancestral Recall this time.

And they're both rogues, so you can also consider building a tribal deck around them.

Wu Spy is yet another rogue that has an etb-ability that offers some topdeck control.
Which means he is great with both the impostor as well as the agent.
And he also works nicely with Auntie's Snitch, which again works nicely with Lore Broker.

Add Cloak and Dagger and you'll be able to shroud any rogue you cast immediately.
On top of that you get a sweet +2/+0 boost. And you can cascade into this equipment, too.

270733: Shardless Agent.author: Ferlord
270733: Shardless Agent.text_parsed:
Cascade is a weird and hard-to-understand ability, but in truth, it's one of the best in the game.

For , you get a 2/2 artifact creature (can help with Metalcraft or Cradlecraft), and you get something that cost less than 3 that isn't a land. In short, you get two cards for one.

It's like a cantrip, but better. Maybe I should call it a roidtrip.

See, you could make your whole deck ONLY have one spell that costs less than 3: Sol Ring? Diving Top? Hypergenesis? Pick your poison, mate.

Once you play him/her, it pretty much becomes a "Search your library for a card with CMC less than 3, and put it into play."

Deceivingly amazing.

270733: Shardless Agent.author: Continue
270733: Shardless Agent.text_parsed:
I've had an opponent ragequit with this card just by pulling Ancestral Vision. Keep in mind that this also gets Baleful Strix, Tarmogoyf, Hymn to Tourach, Umezawa's Jitte, Stoneforge Mystic... not to mention all the cool one-drops it can hit.

@DoragonShinzui — you couldn't be any more wrong. This card is a great representation of Alara post-reunification. It's a Bant-colored artifact creature (perhaps they've teamed up with Esper?) with one of Alara's most-cherished (or most-hated) mechanics. But if you're only looking at the flavor of this card, you're doing it wrong. This is playability first and flavor second.

270736: Felidar Umbra.author: sarroth
270736: Felidar Umbra.text_parsed: @Rav0004: Ooo, an aura with split second, why didn't I think of that? I like it. I still think it's silly that while auras are inherent card disadvantage, 1) some attempts to fix that have made arguably broken cards like Rancor and Aspect of Mongoose, and 2) many players who know better (such as myself) love them anyway. While you can still get 2-for-1'd when your aura with totem armor is on the stack, I think the mechanic was a good step towards helping make auras not so pitifully weak compared to equipment. This card is another good step in that direction. Reminds me of Neurok Stealthsuit, if, again, weaker than equipment.

270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.author: sarroth
270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.text_parsed:
The only thing I wish about this guy was that he said nonland permanent, and said may, so that if you couldn't be even more of a jerk with him than you already would be (White and Green being able to protect him pretty well through shroud/hexproof effects and flicker effects) but wouldn't have to ever choose between attacking and not having to target your own stuff.

Players who love enchantments/auras have some good options for generals; this guy, Zur the Enchanter, Bruna, Light of Alabaster, Hanna, Ship's Navigator, and Uril, the Mistalker (Krond would be good in Uril, too, if your mana fixing is decent enough). Am I missing anyone? I like that Wizards is supporting that deck archetype and allowing multiple decks to run the same theme without feeling too similar.

270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.author: Lief098
270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.text_parsed:
The mana cost is actually part of the charm of this guy for me. For some reason, I just really love huge, oppressive mana costs like the ones on any of the Ultimatums or the one on Progenitus.

Right now I'm trying to pick between this guy and Uril, the Miststalker for a mainly G/W aura-based EDH deck. On the one hand, Uril is really strong with auras, protects himself, and opens me up to a third color. On the other hand, Krond is better flavorwise as a commander, his mana cost is really cool, and I think he'd generally be more fun to play. I'm thinking I'll probably go with Krond on this one.

270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.author: Elegy
270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.text_parsed:
First thing that comes to mind was the tough cost:
Riftstone Portal + Ghost Quarter
Dual lands are overall the way to go, but this is not too tough really.

One deck I've always had was a green/white enchantment-based deck, so I was excited to hear about a new, legendary, mythic rare dedicated to auras and designed with EDH in mind.
The thing about Krond as an aura-based creature is that all he really cares about is "enchant creature".
Some good enchantments for Krond:
Dragon Scales/Dragon Fangs (Instafree-enchant)
Aspect of Mongoose (Yes, shroud means no more other auras, but he only needs one!)
Predatory Urge/Sinstriker's Will (Use that Vigilance)
Elemental Resonance (Use that colorful casting cost)
Rancor
Armadillo Cloak (Stacks with Felidar Umbra and Spirit Loop)
Flickering Ward

When I saw him, I was a bit disappointed. I expected a home-field advantage effect, not powerful removal. And Indrik Umbra enchanting him is half-useless because he flies. (while epic)
He's very scary nonetheless.

270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.author: OffensiveBias
270738: Krond the Dawn-Clad.text_parsed:
NozzDogg, Lightning Greaves does not make auras drop off. Shroud merely prevents him from being the target of new auras as they're cast. That's the only restriction, though. If a Pacifism comes into play via an Academy Rector or Zur the Enchanter, the Pacifism can come into play attached to the shrouded creature.

Protection does make auras fall off, though, unless the aura specifies otherwise.

270743: Mass Mutiny.author: DarthParallax
270743: Mass Mutiny.text_parsed:
probably a Fixed Insurrection. Depends on whether you think Insurrection needed fixing, and whether you think comparing this to Drain Life makes any sense whatsoever (for a turn, not only are you gaining creatures but they're losing creatures, so maybe you can get away with Incremental Steal being good enough?)

I wouldn't really be comfortable playing this in a 3-player game- too much chance that someone's board will be too big for stealing two creatures to be a good enough blowout card- one of the players at the table is bound to be playing some kind of rushing army-summoning deck.
In a 5+ player game, you can double your army, and target One guy who is being a problem. You might have to get permission from the table to use this effectively though.

Insurrection IS a little crazy at Multiplayer games though, actually enabling one person to blow up two or more players at once. I like the one that leaves blockers for your army to fight through, but this doesn't seem strong enough. This model, with just a little more push, would I think be the card's ideal form in Multiplayer.

Suggested Add: "They each fight a creature their owner controls." {4}{R}{R} Yes? :)

271136: Predatory Urge.author: Mode
271136: Predatory Urge.text_parsed:
"Seems unweildy without fight." --kanguilla

Maybe more unweildy to read, but in fact it's a bit better than that. You could call it "first fight":
The damage doesn't happen simultaneously - your creature gets to hit first. And if it hits in a special way (e.g. with wither or death touch), it can alter the outcome from the targeted creature (like dealing less/no damage).
Also see the rulings of Karplusan Yeti, which works the same way.

271137: Armillary Sphere.author: voyager1
271137: Armillary Sphere.text_parsed:
Armillary Sphere is a card that finds its way into my mono-red EDH decks, but little else. This color, in particular, is lacking in two key areas: mana development and card draw. This card contributes a little to both, in a rather indirect way.

Red decks have access to pretty much all the same mana rocks other colors do, but little beyond that baseline to keep pace with other colors' development. While the Sphere doesn't actually accelerate mana, it helps hit land drops. Red needs that extra help when it's not searching up lands in the early game from Brainstorm and Cultivate-type effects. With that dearth of non-land mana sources, red decks really need to hit as many land drops as they can up until the latest stages of the game, in hope to keep up.

Red is lacking in conventional draw, but it's getting ever better at cycling away unwanted cards (via WInds of Change, Incendiary Command, Faithless Looting, Mad Prophet, ect). Armillary Sphere aids with this, padding your hand size to replace through various looting effects. The cards unique to red that actually increase hand size are very few; red decks can't turn their nose up at swapping out a surplus of Mountains for enhanced card selection.

Other colors have access to more powerful draw and/or ramp effects, making Armillary Sphere's roundabout goodness kinda slow and superfluous. It's the card that's always on the cusp of being included, were there not something just a little more straightforward in it's application. It's a shame, too; Armillary Sphere is solid, if just a little unfocused.

OBJECTION! This card is NOT strictly worse then young wolf, it is only used differently. The card by themselves would be clear that one is better then other, but if consider this a token generating deck, then your most likely going to be running Parallel Lives or Doubling Season. Sac it, get 2 1/1s, and get two more things to sac. Young wolf will only return as 2/2, and even with doubling season, it may return a 3/3, but devour works on numbers purely.

Now, doom traveler isn't precisely better either, It's white, and that off color to benefit a devour deck like this is made. Doom Traveler is perfect for the white weenie token decks though. It really all about the situation, and when it comes to devour, this card is great.

271143: Tukatongue Thallid.text_parsed:
The other reason that this isn't strictly worse than Doomed Traveler or Young Wolf is tribal. In an actual thallid deck, between Sporoloth Ancient and Sporesower Thallid this will turn into another token maker if it survives, and if it doesn't survive but the Saproling does, the saproling can be sacced for effect to another saproling.

Not that it's likely you'd run this in a thallid deck, since there are so many better choices, including better 1-drop choices. Unless you need more than 8 one-drops, this won't be used for that much.

271146: Viridian Emissary.author: blurrymadness
271146: Viridian Emissary.text_parsed:
I play this in my own "Card advantage Green" deck. Yavimaya Elder and Krosan Tusker make up the next couple of plays that come after and they all ensure nigh-guaranteed card advantage; keeping me from drawing extra lands while filling my hand and providing beaters/finishers.

If they use kill spells or lose a creature, all the better. If they don't, they take a few damage and eat him in later turns (or in the worst case, he becomes rampant growth that chumps or suicides.)

It definitely adds up when your opponent plays into it *at all*. Best part is that if they don't you have 2 power unblockables all day and the tuskers still keep your land drops flowing. I top off the deck with Rune-scarred Demon and some Psuedo-card advantage cards like Nantuko Cultivator. Life from the loam works well in the deck and Quicksand becomes a {0} kill spell without hurting your mana-base.

That is why this guy is so good. Aggressive body, low cost, card advantage.

271151: Kor Spiritdancer.author: Dark_Angel1981
271151: Kor Spiritdancer.text_parsed: She is in Ajani's deck in the Xbox DoTP 2014 with a ton of auras.....I took out all creatures but her, and a couple others (one is flying double strike for 3 but can't recall name) and took out all stupid enchantments, so its down to 60 cards.  Turn 2, her.  Turn 3, spirit mantle, lifelink.  That make her 5/7 lifelink protection.  Turn 4, the one that gives her flying and +1 for each plains, you have  11/13...or you could just do daybreak coronet and one other 2 drop enchantment..making her at least a 12/15 protection from creatures, lifelink, first strike, vigilance on turn 4.  It's insane.  And in the game, I honestly have to mulligan 2 out of 10 times to get what I need in starting hand to beat you in turn 5.  Even if you have a doom blade or something, there are so many auras in the deck and awesome creatures, you can't catch up.  I never lost w/ that deck setup that way.  It got too easy, so I stopped playing with it in multiplayer.

@Ferlord
All umbras have the appearance and provide qualities of a certain animal.
"Shadowmage" isn't quite an animal :D
Their functionaility is often derived from common traits of creature in Magic.
Bear Umbra gives +2/+2, since a 2/2 creature is considered a "bear".
Crab Umbra provides Horseshoe Crab's ability for its casting cost.
Snake Umbra even combines both a power/toughness boost that suits your common snake and an ability that has been observed on various snakes so far.

(And getting card advantage for letting your creatures hit your opponent is just as blue a it is green.)

271161: Mycoloth.author: Stinga
271161: Mycoloth.text_parsed:
Ima green player through and through
I love my 10/10 trampling over to you
Ramping to six mana on turn three
is a plan that always excites me
But an army of plantlike weenies
Are even better than a couple fat meanies
Some thallids and sprout swarm fill my early game needs
and I hold off agro with scatter the seeds
If I can make it to turn five and my deck turns on
Because there is one special card that I lean
It’s a fungus that can never, ever be beat.
Thallids are pathetic, bred for their meat
Mycoloth guy eats em for breakfast (devour)
It starts as a four/four but runs at sixteen power
A trample-less fattie sure, but it can’t be ignored
Cuz this big beastie pumps out a saproling horde
yeah I know its summer but lets do some math
I want to calculate the damage of my token wrath
Lets say I put down a doubling season
And have four creatures for this reason
Now, here is the fun part
Let the calculations start
Four times two is my mycoloths base food
But doubling season expands its brood
Eight times two is sixteen making him twenty twenty
Whats that you say? Twenty a turn saps is plenty?
Haha! There are never enough my friend
We have more doubling. This is not the end
Twenty times two means fourty saps on the field
But even now my finisher has not been revealed
There is a card that places with mycoloth real well
And it gives anyone in my way some sap flavored hell
An army of fourty has grown from the four sap seed
And now its time for…OVERWHELING STAMPEDE!
Fourty one/ones get a twenty power boost to one shot my foe
And there are forty of them pumped up and ready to go
One last multiplication to do before this match is done
Block eight hundred trample damage or you lose. Have fun!

Are even better than a couple fat meanies
Some thallids and sprout swarm fill my early game needs
and I hold off agro with scatter the seeds
If I can make it to turn five and my deck turns on
Because there is one special card that I lean
It’s a fungus that can never, ever be beat.
Thallids are pathetic, bred for their meat
Mycoloth guy eats em for breakfast (devour)
It starts as a four/four but runs at sixteen power
A trample-less fattie sure, but it can’t be ignored
Cuz this big beastie pumps out a saproling horde
yeah I know its summer but lets do some math 
I want to calculate the damage of my token wrath
Lets say I put down a doubling season 
And have four creatures for this reason
Now, here is the fun part
Let the calculations start
Four times two is my mycoloths base food
But doubling season expands its brood
Eight times two is sixteen making him twenty twenty
Whats that you say? Twenty a turn saps is plenty?
Haha! There are never enough my friend
We have more doubling. This is not the end
Twenty times two means fourty saps on the field
But even now my finisher has not been revealed
There is a card that places with mycoloth real well
And it gives anyone in my way some sap flavored hell 
An army of fourty has grown from the four sap seed
And now its time for…OVERWHELING STAMPEDE!
Fourty one/ones get a twenty power boost to one shot my foe
And there are forty of them pumped up and ready to go
One last multiplication to do before this match is done
Block eight hundred trample damage or you lose. Have fun!

271161: Mycoloth.author: Krysto
271161: Mycoloth.text_parsed:
Wow, the reprint of this is rated significantly lower than the original print, which is strange.

I see no reason to hate this card - at it's worst it's a 4/4 for 5 cmc, which isn't too bad (who am I kidding, if you hardcast this thing and it gets flickered I'd be happy just to HAVE a 4/4 if the opponent's controlling), not to mention you still get the chance to re-devour should this happen. He combos incredibly well with himself, especially if you can get him off the battlefield and back onto it, and with a few creature tokens he might as well be a win-condition of his own. With a lot of cards, it's only your own fault if you put all of your eggs in his basket, but that doesn't make him bad - you take the same risk playing just about any card - heck, even Emrakul can get foiled by some well-played spells and giving this fellow Hexproof is far from impossible. You can boost his counters and accelerate the token production and if you're playing around with tokens while we're at it, he's a darn good source of them.

So why the hate, or at least the lack of love? He's a big target, but so are a lot of things, and if your opponent can't respond, the number of turns they have left just got significantly shorter.

This thing's a monstrosity, even if you only feed it one creature it comes in as a 6/6 with 2 saprolings per turn, and if you feed it 2 that's an 8/8 that puts out 4.

Mycoloth needs more love - especially with Selesnya BACK on the table.

271161: Mycoloth.author: Aquillion
271161: Mycoloth.text_parsed:
@Continue: This card's low rating is because it dies to Doom Blade.

Yes, yes, I know. But it's a more serious problem with Devour than it is with (say) a Baneslayer Angel, because this card pretty much requires at least one sacrifice to be worthwhile. And if it immediately gets hit by removal, you're down two cards to your opponent's one.

Additionally, you need another creature to sacrifice or it's generally going to suck -- it essentially shares the problems creature enchantments have (and almost no creature enchantments get used unless they have some special feature that protects them from the 2-for-1 danger.)

It's fun when it works, but it's a risky card to play.
271161: Mycoloth.text_posted:

271162: Thorn-Thrash Viashino.author: MechaKraken
271162: Thorn-Thrash Viashino.text_parsed:
As long as you can protect him, this guy can become a bomb in any creature heavy deck. Run him in jund decks and pair him up with Skeletal Grimace and Lightning Greaves. You now have a cheap, regenerating, untargetable trample that can be pumped with devour.

Path to Exile was this guy's main problem in shards, but in legacy there are ways to deal with it. Since your running black you can remove it from their hand with duress before they can even play it, then use haunting echoes or surgical extraction or memoricide to get rid of it for good.

271163: Thunder-Thrash Elder.author: JaxsonBateman
271163: Thunder-Thrash Elder.text_parsed:
@VonDread - it's not rated higher because it's a 1/1 unless you give yourself card disadvantage. It's why most devour cards are underwhelming - because to actually get their upside, you need to invest into some card disadvantage. Admittedly, some of the better ones more than pay you back for it if they're allowed to live, like Mycoloth or Voracious Dragon, but this guy is just a vanilla creature that can get removed in a plethora of ways, leaving you at least 2 creatures down (this guy plus the one/s he ate).

If he lives though, and is allowed to connect, then sure, a 4/4+ for 3 is always going to be good. Most better decks would rather just play unconditionally good creatures though. ;-)

271164: Last Stand.author: shotoku64
271164: Last Stand.text_parsed:
I don't really like this card. It doesn't have such a huge effect that other 5 color cards need, considering how difficult they are to cast. Let's break this down.
Turn 5 (assuming no tricks like Prismatic Omen or dual lands)
{W} worse than healing salve (less life gain)
{U} worse than preordain/ponder(less card advantage)
{B} worse than bump in the night(less damage)
{R} worse than Lightning bolt(less damage and can only hit creatures)
{G} worse than sprout (not an instant)
(Note all the above cards are commons, this Last Stand is rare)

This also is requiring that you pulled this off will all basics, or you have the alpha or ravnica duals with the basic land types. If you use any other lands the effects will be even less fantastic, because if you use a glacial fortress rather than a plains you don't even get the life gain.

Obviously this is supposed to be played with snazzy dual-land-types-lands or prismatic omen, but even then there are more consistent, more powerful, and more fun things to do with {WUBRG}

271164: Last Stand.author: Salient
271164: Last Stand.text_parsed:
Hang on, let me tutor my Academy Rector and a sacrifice outlet so that I can fetch Prismatic Omen. And a Sterling Grove or Privileged Position to protect the Omen... alright, now all I have to do is Infernal Tutor for Last Stand... Alright! Ready to rock off your socks! I can kill one creature, nearly kill one opponent, get a bunch of 1/1s, regain some of the life I've lost so far, and dig through my deck to find Ill-Gotten Gains or Conflux so I can do all this again!

If it floats your boat, by all means, knock yourself out. Some people just want to watch the world turn.

But understand that you're doing a classic Johnny thing, making awesomeness out of a normally terrible card. You shouldn't get offended when other players call the card awful, you should agree with them, and be proud that you found a way to break such a piece of trash!

I've really come around to this card now. It's a bit random; but it is card advantage creature kill which is hard to come by. Feels a little odd you might hit another kill spell. I'd prefer to run it in R/B burn-control:
-It's damage, so if you put it on a big creature, you'll probably hit more burn to finish it off
-It puts more cards in the 'yard than normal, working with Lavamancer
-If you kill the creature you may kill another or burn their face
-Running into Koth would be pretty freaking awesome
-Same with Flametongue Kavu. Potential 3-for-1 there :D

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: CorkBulb
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
Great new art on a great card! The new art really displays the power of this card. She looks like she's ready to kill, and she probably is!

I run this in my red/green speed aggro deck (duh) and I usually cascade into a Colossal Might or a lightning bolt, which just makes my opponents cry. All the cards in the deck except this one are CMC 3 or less, and all the creatures have haste, so I'm gonna get something extra to smash with. Then if I'm lucky enough to play another one next turn, it's usually GG. This usually winds up being my finisher along with the other creatures. The haste just makes it all the better, since you can attack if you cascade into a buff spell playing it on her if you don't have any other creatures.

My only complaint is the P/T is a bit low, but for the abilities vs the CMC it's above the curve.

4.5/5 great card

EDIT: Ah right, you cannot cast a buff spell onto the elf since cascade triggers "as you cast", not "as it enters the battlefield". Still, Lightning Bolt....

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: Ligerman30
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
I think people hate on the card not because of it's actual power level of the creature itself but, because of the mechanic. I played this card during Alara, it's wonderful, but, it's just another cascade card. Cascade was a pretty busted, especially in a good deck. But, a 3/2 haste for body is honestly not that great any more. He doesn't even trade with Attended Knight, which is only really going to be used in limited. And what he does trade with i.e. Gravecrawler & Elite Vanguard cost to cast. He should have been a hill giant with cascade but, w/o the haste. Having only 2 toughness on a 4 cmc creature doesn't sit well with me, especially in green.

4/5

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: psychichobo
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
Guys, the reason people feared and loved this card was that it sat at a convenient middle point to be cascaded into and to cascade into other things. There's a lot of 5 CMC cascade spells that would have their effect, flow into this, and this in turn would go into something else. For example, Bituminous Blast, Bloodbraid Elf, Blightning. For 5 mana you just did 8 damage to your opponent, dropped a creature with haste onto the field, and had them discard two cards.

You're not just getting a 3/2 with haste for 4 mana - lands don't count for cascade so basically you'd be getting a 3/2 with haste and some other card that could be awesome - from a creature to a buff to a burn.

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: DarthParallax
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
Also, Wizards pretty much has to pander to collectors in some ways- yes it's technically 'popular' right now- really stinking popular actually- but MTG has a pretty huge turnover rate of players. They gain new players but they also lose new and old players and a lot of their money comes from Old Players building and saving for their Legacy and Commander careers. So they aren't going to be making the most careful choices for Modern and Standard because they pretty much know at this point that Legacy and Commander are what they want players to be playing if they actually want really Returning Customers.

They make a big deal about Standard and Modern, but it's as much for getting Old Players to try New cards as it is to get New Players to play at all. If they really thought they could work on Modern and Standard being their Best Formats, and having that Actually Work, they'd...well, they'd plain Stahp making Legacy-playables. They keep makin' em though. Just enough to keep us all on our toes and interested. How much of their interesting stuff is based on "What Exciting Reprints can we get?" vs how much is "What Exciting New Thing is coming?"
It's close to even split Old vs. New, and it would be way heavily skewed towards everything being New New NEW if WoTC didn't think that the Collectors and Old Players were a seriously important demographic to cater to.

Also, Goyf might be bannable but Dark Confidant isn't. For what it's worth, Necropotence isn't banned in Commander. "Life for Cards" is a REALLY good strategy, but it's not apparently sharply enough broken to be "Kill on Sight" in Development or the DCI. We actually get to have it as aggressively as Sign in Blood in Standard. I'm not saying that Bob isn't really really good. Him and The Skull are both Fantastic in Modern (Bob) and Commander (Skull) respectively, but it seems that Legacy is the only place where this is "Too Much Power" and it's outright not allowed.

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: SAUS3
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
@Ligerman30
No. If this was just 4 mana cascade and nothing else, it would be bad. If this was just a 3/2 haste for 4, it would be bad.

The reason this card is so strong is because if you look at a 3/2 haste, it could easily cost 3 mana. It wouldn't be a particularly good card, but it would be a decent common.

With that, you get a cascade tacked on for 1 mana.

Now, the creature is still weak at 3/2, but when you cascade, you could hit a multitude of things.

You can hit removal - clear a blocker that will kill it.
You can hit a creature - getting them to trade with this will let your other creature through later.
Various other things - you get a big value boost on your 3/2 haste (if you land a good 3 mana spell, you basically paid 4 mana for a 6 mana spell).

This card is typically used in aggro decks. Your 1, 2, and 3 drops will still be in effect when you play this card. That means that even if they have a blocker that can trade with it, they may have to let your putrid leech or tarmogoyf through.

This card is hated on because it brings a ton of value to an aggressive creature, which means aggro decks get great value cards.

Imagine bloodbraid elf read:
3/2 haste, when you cast it, destroy target nonland permanent and each other permanent with the same name. (maelstrom pulse).

That's pretty damn busted.

271167: Bloodbraid Elf.author: sweetgab
271167: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
Bloodbraid Elf into Blightning. This was in Standard back then.

2RG 3/2 haste, when it etb, target opponent discards two cards and takes 3 damage.

Card advantage: +2. This is on par with a pure draw spell in blue (Concentrate). But wait, there's more!
Damage: 3 to 6 depending on if she connects.
Board presence: you get a 3/2.

So this is like a Concentrate that Lava Axes your opponent and lets you play a free mid-sized creature. It's like a mini-Cruel Ultimatum, except that it sits at a comfortable four mana, which means you don't need to worry much about defending yourself as in the case with Cruel Ultimatum. As long as you aren't a goldfish on your second and third turn, spamming Bloodbraid Elves / Bituminous Blast is both your best defense and your route to victory.

And now you know why Jund was, for a time, pretty much the only deck in Standard.

271169: Enigma Sphinx.author: Living_Wings
271169: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed: Why hasn't this been changed to "When Enigma Sphinx dies..."?
271169: Enigma Sphinx.text_posted: Why hasn't this been changed to "When Enigma Sphinx dies..."?

271169: Enigma Sphinx.author: Spheniscine
271169: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed:
Living_Wings: Because of control effects.

The current wording specifies "put into your (i.e. this creature's controller's) graveyard from the battlefield". Therefore it only triggers if the owner of Enigma Sphinx still controls it. If I Mind Control your Enigma Sphinx and it dies, it doesn't go to my graveyard (it goes to yours), so it won't trigger.

However, "dies" means "put into any graveyard from the battlefield". If this card said 'dies' instead, it would trigger even if the controller is not the owner of the card. Thus if I Mind Control your Enigma Sphinx and it dies, the ability would trigger, but I would control the trigger. Therefore, the Enigma Sphinx would go into my library, even though you own the card! This, obviously, is not desirable in non-silver-bordered Magic.

271170: Enlisted Wurm.author: nemokara
271170: Enlisted Wurm.text_parsed:
@Goatllama, just because 14 1/1 humans could easily kill a 5/5 in your combat phase doesn't mean they are superior flavorfully.

First of all, yes, groups of humans have a history of being able to hunt and kill huge creatures. But there's always risk involved in such a matchup - even though 14 humans could kill this wurm, it would in turn kill five of them. In terms of flavor I would classify almost 40% casualties as "having trouble" bringing down something.

Also, remember there's a difference between the flavor of killing something in combat and bringing it under your power to fight for you. Three 1/1 soldiers could kill a 3/3 elephant. But would those same three soldiers have an easy time harnessing the elephant to fight for their side? I doubt it.

271187: Throat Slitter.author: Kaleidostorm
271187: Throat Slitter.text_parsed:
This card is way better than the rating suggests. It ninjutsus in for 3, so you can thwack your opponent with liliana's specter, bring it back to your hand, ninja this lovely lady in for 3. It is essentially a 3 mana "destroy target nonblack creature, deal 2 damage blah blah" spell (well, 6 if you include the specter, but the specter's for the discard anyways). Next main phase you can slap lightning greaves on her or even better, whispersilk cloak

Send that specter back out and make the opponent discard, thwack with throat slitter to your heart's content to nuke key creatures, and do that until you ninja out Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni or something and start nabbing those critters you murdered.

For added effect use some swarmyards to help keep your ratties on the board.

Ninjutsu is really good for returning creatures that have a "enter the battlefield" trigger.

This card can make the game for you if you can consistently destroy a creature every turn.

Oh, and I'm pretty sure ninjutsu'd creatures can't be countered since it's an ability that puts it into play, not a casting cost.

271189: Kathari Remnant.author: Hydr0
271189: Kathari Remnant.text_parsed:
Now this is interesting. As a no-damage flier with a cheap regenerate cost, the ideal place to run this is a U/B control deck (or any U/B deck that wants to stall for time), but only if you aren't running reactive spells. Cascading into a counterspell is pretty useless, and since when does U/B control not run counterspells?

Still, I think there are certain combo decks that really ought to take a look at this dude. IN THE EVENT that you aren't running counterspells or other reactive instants (i.e, spells you don't want to cascade into), the card advantage here is actually really nice. He chump-blocks all day long, and he gives you a free spell when you cast him.

271189: Kathari Remnant.author: sweetgab
271189: Kathari Remnant.text_parsed:
I like to think of the Alara Reborn developer team as two distinct groups: some of those people were clearly aware of the power of cascade, and they made this pretty balanced card; some other people completely missed it, and they made Bloodbraid Elf.

Let's compare the two, and see how much they missed! We assume this card is balanced. Will-of-the-Wisp is one mana. A 3/2 haste is four mana (Vulshok Berserker), and if you really push it you might be able to get a 3/2 haste for three, that's about as good as it gets. So Bloodbraid Elf was about two full mana too cheap, or maybe one-and-a-half if you find six mana a bit too steep a cost (see Enlisted Wurm). That's not quite as bad as Ancestral Recall (three mana too cheap compared to Concentrate), but it's kind of close.

271195: Mitotic Slime.author: Radagast
271195: Mitotic Slime.text_parsed: A fun, flavorful card that brings back memories (nightmares?) of a time when our adventuring party was attacked at night in the Underdark. Having no idea what was heading towards us, I cast a Blade Barrier to shield the party. That was great, until we learned that it was a Black Pudding, an Ooze that basically splits up like this critter when dealt enough damage by sharp objects. Much running and screaming followed, though we were victorious in the end. Fun card!

In the token deck I run, I don't have many creatures above 3/3, so I can see this card as interchangeable. The only thing I really think Overwhelming Stampede has on this is that it's {3}{G}{G}

but for the low mana cost of 5, why not just run both of them? Got 10 man? Use Overrun to boost the power of your creatures then up it with Overwhelming Stampede based on the new, higher power totals :D

271201: Overrun.author: Aquillion
271201: Overrun.text_parsed:
This is stronger than Overwhelming Stampede in the right deck (though that card is good, too.)

Here's how you use this card: Play a bunch of one-mana or two-mana creatures each turn leading up to turn 5, then play Overrun and swing for game. Very few decks can react quickly enough to avoid dying. With Overwhelming Stampede, that doesn't work as reliably, because there are so few creatures that exceed 3 power and can still be rushed out.
