271212: Selesnya Sanctuary.author: tankthebest
271212: Selesnya Sanctuary.text_parsed:
I think a lot of people are missing the value of the Ravnica Karoo lands. You don't have to return an untapped land to your hand when you play this.

For example, on turn three you can tap two lands, play a two-drop, then play this and return one of the tapped lands to your hand. Then on turn four you can play the land you returned and you'll have four mana available. You lose tempo by not being able to play a card where you normally could (three-drop on turn three, etc), but you gain mana fixing.

Non-basic land destruction will hurt you a lot if one of these gets hit with it, so watch for that. It also loses some of the versatility of the dual lands that let you choose which color to add to your mana pool.

However, these cards work very well with Amulet of Vigor and land untapping effects.

In addition, they're a cost-effective alternative for mana fixing in your deck if you don't feel like spending $5.00+ on a single dual land.

Oh, and for the hundredth time, if you play one of these with no other lands on the field, you'll have to return it to your hand.
271212: Selesnya Sanctuary.text_posted:
I think a lot of people are missing the value of the Ravnica Karoo lands. You don't have to return an [i]untapped[/i] land to your hand when you play this.

For example, on turn three you can tap two lands, play a two-drop, then play this and return one of the tapped lands to your hand. Then on turn four you can play the land you returned and you'll have four mana available. You lose tempo by not being able to play a card where you normally could (three-drop on turn three, etc), but you gain mana fixing.

Non-basic land destruction will hurt you a lot if one of these gets hit with it, so watch for that. It also loses some of the versatility of the dual lands that let you choose which color to add to your mana pool.

However, these cards work very well with [autocard]Amulet of Vigor[/autocard] and land untapping effects.

In addition, they're a cost-effective alternative for mana fixing in your deck if you don't feel like spending $5.00+ on a single dual land.

Oh, and for the hundredth time, if you play one of these with no other lands on the field, you'll have to return it to your hand.

271212: Selesnya Sanctuary.author: CaptainBlue
271212: Selesnya Sanctuary.text_parsed:
These types of lands are actually quite useful in decks that use a lot of land-based strategies. Non-basic lands which have an "enter the battlefield" ability can be returned to your hand and later reused. Landfall abilities can be triggered more often; especially if this land bounces itself. Also, if an opponent has attached something harmful, like an enchantment or one of Obsidian Fireheart's burn counters to a land of yours, you can bounce it back.

It won't win you any races without Amulet of Vigor, but I like the mana fixing, needing less total lands in my deck and being able to reuse my Sejiri Steppe.

4/5

271214: Dimir Infiltrator.text_parsed:
@ subatomica:
"202.3b When calculating the converted mana cost of an object with {X} in its mana cost, X is treated as 0 while the object is not on the stack, and X is treated as the number chosen for it while the object is on the stack."

So you can absolutely use it to pull Mind Grind.

271216: Inkfathom Witch.author: Ladon---
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_parsed:
@ClockworkSwordfish, @RAV004: See Rule 509.1h - A creature isn't considered an unblocked creature until after the Declare Blocker's step. It is also impossible to Ninjutsu until after the Declare Blocker's step, because a creature isn't considered unblocked until that point. To sum it up, this won't let you trade in combat!

You could choose not to block any of your opponents' creatures, activate the ability and then ping their biggest threats or use Carnifex Demon's ability to do a psuedo-board wipe.

The cheap cost, ease of casting, and fear make this good for Ninjutsu, and the ability can win you games thanks to all the evasion the Ninja deck has. 3.5/5 from me.

271216: Inkfathom Witch.author: Zaroganos
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_parsed: Really confused, why is this creature's fear (precursor of intimidate?) only count for non-black and non-artifact? Shouldn't it also count toward non-blue?
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_posted: Really confused, why is this creature's fear (precursor of intimidate?) only count for non-black and non-artifact? Shouldn't it also count toward non-blue?

271216: Inkfathom Witch.author: Amorgan
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_parsed:
@ Ladon---, thanks for clearing that up for the others.

@ClockworkSwordfish, you're a little confused, this activation requires both and , so mono-colored is not going to work there.

@Zaroganos it's a reprint of an old card. The reason they got rid of "Fear" in the first place was because the actual keyword only refered to and (typically) interacted with creatures. When they "removed" Fear, they basically wanted to make it for all the colors with one keyword ("Intimidate") that way the language for fear (Which was, no matter what color the card was, "can only be blocked by black and/or artifact creatures.", which is too specific to warrant it's own keyword. So, now we have Intimidate, "can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it", so that we can give it to all the colors AND it makes multi-colored cards w/intimidate more easily blocked (IE: Vela the Night-Clad)

Basically, turn any unblocked guy into a 4/1, opponents or your own. Not bad, just not too good unless you're swinging with 5 guys that cannot be blocked...

Which rarely happens in the control heavy , so this card is in the wrong color.

271216: Inkfathom Witch.author: Mode
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_parsed:
Note that it says each, not target, which might be the reason why it was included in Planechase, since it also affects creatures you don't control - well, aside from the fact that there's also Wizards' obvious intention that you use this ability with umblocked Ninjas.

You can always simply skip blocking and turn your opponents' creatures into fragile 4/1s, which can get pretty ridiculous with the right means to deal the damage (e.g. through Goblin Sharpshooter).
And it has yet another use on your opponents' turns - turning Timmy's fatties into 4/1s can save you a lot of trouble.

And the witch even has Fear (which in this case is more handy than Intimidate, too), so you'll get to use the ability on herself for a considerable boost in power.
Of course, this card is also potentially crazy with tokens.
Plus it is an easy to cast hybrid card. And it also has considerable tribal types.

Overall this looks like a nice card with awesome combo potential.

271216: Inkfathom Witch.author: questionflanger
271216: Inkfathom Witch.text_parsed: This guy is so sneaky! I had Curse of Death's Hold on an opponent and he attacked with everything. I activated his ability (don't forget it works on your opponent's creatures!) and didn't declare any blockers. All his creatures went to zero; hello, board wipe. The same trick works great with the -1/-1 ability on Golgari Charm. Once you've done it a few times your opponent's will start bombing him because you can't be trusted when he's out. That's the mark of a great card to me.

Love the new art, but I'm getting kinda sick of seeing this in every damn precon I buy.

Especially in a ninja-themed precon; I get that you're supposed to bounce him for ninjutsu and recast him to abuse his etb ability, but I'd rather leave the nonblack creature destruction to Throat Slitter and recast an Ornithopter or Tormented Soul every turn than keep paying six mana (which you can probably only afford every other turn), especially so late in the game when most decks will have defenses against fliers and his 3 power won't ever actually damage the opponent when I have ninja in my hand.

271218: Assassinate.author: Atali
271218: Assassinate.text_parsed:
The reasoning behind putting this into the precon is that it's easy to see that it needs to be replaced, and there are many upgrades to choose from. Wizards doesn't want to print optimized precons, because they want players to have the fun of tinkering with their new decks, and buy more cards in the process.
Go for the Throat would be my ideal replacement, though compelling arguments can be made for many cards. Peel from Reality would provide some nice utility, and can help remove obstacles for to your Ninjas.

271227: Khalni Garden.author: Dragonshoredreamz
271227: Khalni Garden.text_parsed:
I like this card. It comes in handy for my mono-green token deck.

A worthwhile bonus. If you're playing a Land, why not get a creature out of it?
Sure you could be just playing a 1/1 that only costs one green Mana though at the same time I like that it's an auto-plant token. There are plenty of uses for token creatures and that can't always be said about other non-token creatures you have on the battlefield.

Just as an example: If I play Jaddi Lifestrider...why tap my non-token creatures when I can just tap my abundance of tokens?

In any other green deck though...I probably wouldn't have this since I usually need immediate access to Mana.

271235: Lumberknot.author: Stonedman36
271235: Lumberknot.text_parsed:
Quick question here?

My friend just got a (DA) "Grave Power" Deck which is based on putting monsters into the graveyard to power up his other monsters.

My question is this - When a creature go's from the library to the graveyard dose that creature "Die"? If so Lumberknot seems like a great counter to his discard deck.
271235: Lumberknot.text_posted:
Quick question here? 

My friend just got a (DA) "Grave Power" Deck which is based on putting monsters into the graveyard to power up his other monsters. 

My question is this - When a creature go's from the library to the graveyard dose that creature "Die"? If so Lumberknot seems like a great counter to his discard deck.

271235: Lumberknot.author: alphagprime
271235: Lumberknot.text_parsed: @ Stonedman36: "Dies" is defined as the movement of any creature from the battlefield to the graveyard. If it enters the graveyard from any other location (i.e.- your hand, your library, or exile) then is not considered to have died. Also, if a creature is removed from the battlefield and is prevented from ever even entering the graveyard then it is also considered to have not died. (i.e- Pillar of Flame, Rest in Peace, and Oblivion Ring)
271235: Lumberknot.text_posted: @ Stonedman36: "Dies" is defined as the movement of any creature from the battlefield to the graveyard. If it enters the graveyard from any other location (i.e.- your hand, your library, or exile) then is not considered to have died. Also, if a creature is removed from the battlefield and is prevented from ever even entering the graveyard then it is also considered to have not died. (i.e- [autocard]Pillar of Flame[/autocard], [autocard]Rest in Peace[/autocard], and [autocard]Oblivion Ring[/autocard])

271238: Quiet Disrepair.author: CaptainBlue
271238: Quiet Disrepair.text_parsed:
This card seems to get mixed feelings because of its lack of speed. I can understand that, but what makes it stand out to me is that not only is it a permanent but an enchantment as well. Unlike a lot of instants or sorceries that are only used once and discarded, this can be returned from the graveyard through cards like Auramancer, Dowsing Shaman or Nature's Spiral. Being an enchantment aura allows for synergy with cards such as Mesa Enchantress, Kor Spiritdancer, Celestial Ancient and Totem-guide Hartebeest to name only a few. Also, the life gain has its uses when considering things like Searing Meditation or Ajani's Pridemate and surpasses other options (Ajani's Mantra). What I'm saying is, if you're just looking for removal you should probably look elsewhere, but if you're using a deck that is able to make use of this card's type and/or life gain option, then the bonuses it can offer in terms of synergy can far outweigh its slowness.

3.5/5

275255: Beast Within.author: CorkBulb
275255: Beast Within.text_parsed:
This is what green has needed for a long time. Good green removal. It takes out a *permanent*, giving green a direct way to deal with planeswalkers. It is also more versatile, able to do what a Vindicate can do, at INSTANT SPEED, for only one colored mana. The 3/3 beast token is barely a drawback compared to what you can remove with this, and can even be exploited. If needed, you can even use it on one of your own permanents, including a land, to use as a chump blocker during an opponent's attack, or to remove a pesky enchantment or equipment on an attacking creature to bring it down to size during combat.

This is a good example of "just when you thought you won the game GUESS WHAT? You didn't...."

4.5/5 for excellent green removal

275256: Brutalizer Exarch.text_parsed:
@doitpow - Brutalizer Exarch's second ability can only target noncreature permanents. Blightsteel Colossus is a creature.

@kmn483 - Since both triggers happen at the same time and you control both of them, you can choose which order they are put on the stack. 275256: Brutalizer Exarch.text_posted:
@doitpow - Brutalizer Exarch's second ability can only target noncreature permanents. [autocard]Blightsteel Colossus[/autocard] is a creature.

@kmn483 - Since both triggers happen at the same time and you control both of them, you can choose which order they are put on the stack. This allows you to manipulate the stack in such a way that you CAN search your library for a creature card and put it on top of your library, then draw it with [autocard]Garruk's Packleader[/autocard]'s triggered ability.

4/5

275260: Three Dreams.author: The_Jabberwocky
275260: Three Dreams.text_parsed:
I'm really surprised this isn't rated higher. Sure, its slow, but it provides excellent card advantage and it allows you to tailor pull 3 cards that you need the most. You can pull Auras of any color which there are a ridiculous amount of from all of the Magic sets printed to date. It also only costs a single colored white mana and 4 colorless, so it is very splashable in multi-colored decks. For those having trouble, here are just a few of the cards you can pull:
Angelic Destiny Animate Dead Armadillo Cloak Arrest Blanchwood Armor Control Magic Rancor Pacifism Prison Term Flickering Ward Robe of Mirrors Pariah
..... and the list goes on and on.

275262: Wall of Blossoms.author: JaxsonBateman
275262: Wall of Blossoms.text_parsed:
A lovely card for any Gx deck that's more about control than aggression. Offers a solid defender against many 1-3 drops, and hell, even if it buys the farm after just one block, you haven't lost any cards from it.

As an ETB it's also abusable by many recursion elements like Mimic Vat or Sheoldred, and as a green wall it even helps ramp alongside Overgrown Battlement and Axebane Guardian. All in all, very solid card.

Of course, if you're looking for a more aggressive power/toughness and lack of defender for the same cost, there's always Elvish Visionary.

275264: Ghostly Prison.author: Antsache
275264: Ghostly Prison.text_parsed:
@ Prof_Apoptosis

No, it doesn't negate the effect of any other attack-preventing abilities. Ghostly Prison is worded specifically to avoid such possibilities. It says "...pays {2} for each creature he or she controls that is attacking you." For the Prison's ability to be relevant, creatures have to be able to be declared as attackers. While the Prison allows declaration of attackers pending its condition being met, Peacekeeper outright prevents the declaration of an attacker. Since no creatures can become attackers with Peacekeeper out, Ghostly Prison's ability will never take effect so long as both are on the board.

Edit: Well, rather, it will be in effect, but it will never be relevant (as Peacekeeper will prevent one of its conditions from being met: that of creatures being declared as attackers).
275264: Ghostly Prison.text_posted:

While the Prison allows declaration of attackers pending its condition being met, Peacekeeper outright prevents the declaration of an attacker.  Since no creatures can become attackers with Peacekeeper out, Ghostly Prison's ability will never take effect so long as both are on the board.

Edit: Well, rather, it will be in effect, but it will never be relevant (as Peacekeeper will prevent one of its conditions from being met: that of creatures being declared as attackers).

276068: Fires of Yavimaya.author: jetzine
276068: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
WHY THE SAC IS RELEVANT:

Fires was traditionally played in the context of efficient, undercosted, BIG creature threats like Blastoderm ( for 5 power) or Shivan Wurm ( for 7 power). Or cards like Saproling Burst, which net you 12 damage for 5 mana when the tokens have haste.

You're probably thinking that 5 damage on turn 3 followed by 17 on turn 4 will get you there. This is generally the case (or the fix, as it was called), but Fires doesn't always get those kinds of draws. The thing that enables a total shut-out in a strong matchup where the opponent is capable of neutralizing some of these threats quickly is the extra 2 points of damage. It's that extra 2 damage that pushes it over the edge, even if its on a lone Birds of Paradise flying over their team. It's an instant speed ability, and it has the ability to come out of nowhere. It also makes the playing of multiple Fires in the mid-late game a viable thing.

The Fires deck is the ultimate R/G aggro deck in my opinion. It combines brute force with ferocious speed. It's about blowing your opponent out with more damage than they can count early in the game, and that extra 2 points goes the distance. Trust me.

276068: Fires of Yavimaya.author: limejuicepowder
276068: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
I'm sure it's just me, but never once have I seen this card preform as people say it's capable of. Here's my problems: Casting something for 3 that's not a creature seriously hurts the speed of the assault, haste or not. Thus, even when I draw it my opening hand, I feel like I waste a turn playing fires, just so my creature can attack instantly next turn, when I could have just played the creature this turn and attack the next turn. This leads in to my second point: if you don't draw it in the opening hand with mana accelerator and a beefy creature that costs 4, roughly 75% of it's power is gone. I have a hard time making a deck around that. Yes, it's awesome when birds and blasto and burst are all in the opening draw, but besides that....regular ol' stompy is better, and sligh is even better than that.

Straight from personal experience, 2/5.

276068: Fires of Yavimaya.author: GrimjawxRULES
276068: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
@limejuicepowder: Your comment made me think and I can definitely see where you're coming from. A lot of / aggro decks these days would likely be happier to run cards like Boggart Ram-Gang instead of this. Cascading a Bloodbraid Elf into Boggart Ram-Gang or Violent Outburst is in many cases better than hitting a Fires.
The more I think about it, the more I find it likely that I'd just splash for a Madrush Cyclops or maybe even consider running Hellraiser Goblin, because the biggest weakness of Fires in a regular / deck is the fact that it isn't a creature. And those two extra damage from Fires' buff? Well, now that you've got an additional 2/2 or 3/4 on the field you should technically still be in good shape.

276068: Fires of Yavimaya.author: Shiizu
276068: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
Don't misunderstand this card. This is not just haste. It's second ability is just as important.

This card is never dead assuming you have creatures in hand or in play. It can be used for offense and for defense. It makes combat math a real headache for your opponent and it's definitely one of those cards that can just lead into a sequence of plays that flattens your opponent because you're just a turn too fast. And it's not even bad in multiples.

Plus, never forget that this card actually helps against wrath. Your opponent wraths, and you can just follow-up by beating him down with a creature you kept in your hand. If he's low you might even use the +2/+2 too and kill him.

276068: Fires of Yavimaya.author: RedJaron
276068: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
@lime and @grim, You both have very valid points. However, understand that when Fires was first printed, Blood-Braids and Boggart Gangs were still years away. At that time, the only mass haste cards available were this and Fervor. / stompy had a very different tempo than they do now. Considering Fires was an uncommon to Fervor's rare, it was a lot easier to get a playset, too. And unlike the Cyclops, this is mass haste on an enchantment, not a creature, so it's not subject to combat tricks. The sac ability means a second fires is more than just a backup to removal.

Most Fires decks had healthy mana ramping with Llanowars and Birds, meaning this was usually a T2 drop. That meant dropping a hasted Blastoderm, Balduvian Horde, Hunted Wumpus, Flametongue Kavu, or any number of 4/4 or bigger creatures on T3. Yes, you might lose the creature race for that one turn you drop the Fires, but building a hasted deck means you should take that into consideration. Yes, you'll take a jab to the face now, but next turn you're countering with hay-makers. I've even seen this splashed into Elf decks, meaning Elves hit the board as fast as you get them in your hand.

Yes, there are similar cards that serve the purpose better in different styles and tempos. I'm sure there's a fair amount of nostalgia about this card ( I know I have some. ) But Fires is still very relevant when used the proper way.
